title: The Tale of the Snail Slime Wrangler
intro: Mucus is a miracle of evolution, and some researchers are trying to re-create what nature makes naturally.

transcript.author: Taylor Knapp:
transcript.text: You know, initially I was like, “Sure, come on out and take some slime, if that’s what you need to do.” You know, I didn’t, I really didn’t ask him any questions.

transcript.author: Christopher Intagliata:
transcript.text: On the far eastern edge of Long Island, New York, there's a very peculiar farm that produces a lot of slime, and it’s inspiring scientists to make futuristic materials.

transcript.author: Taylor Knapp:
transcript.text: My name is Taylor Knapp. I’m the head snail wrangler at Peconic Escargot on Long Island in New York.

transcript.author: Intagliata (tape):
transcript.text: So snail wrangling is a real job?

transcript.author: Knapp
transcript.text: Well, it’s a real made-up job. Yes, I think it’s funny, but it also conjures up this image of a snail ranch.

transcript.author: Intagliata (tape):
transcript.text: Do you have a lasso or something?

transcript.author: Knapp
transcript.text: Very tiny lassos—dental floss. Yeah. Yeah.

transcript.author: Intagliata (tape):
transcript.text: Really?

transcript.author: Knapp
transcript.text: No, no, no, no, not really. No, no, no lassos.

transcript.author: Intagliata (tape):
transcript.text: [laughs] I was like, “This job’s getting weirder than I thought.”

transcript.author: Intagliata
transcript.text: This is Christopher Intagliata, and you’re listening to Scientific American’s Science, Quickly. Today I’m taking you on the final leg of our three-part Fascination on slime. We’re gonna start at a snail farm and end up in space. So back to Taylor, the snail wrangler. He starts his career in fine dining, and then one day he's trying to find fresh, local snails so he can prepare escargot. But he can't find any, and instead he sort of finds his calling.

transcript.author: Knapp
transcript.text: The initial idea was very kind of silly. I just noticed that there were no snail farms in the U.S.... I knew that the best restaurants in America had snails on their menu, which means that they were using canned snails.

transcript.author: Intagliata
transcript.text: Taylor thinks, ‘That’s absurd.’ So he starts his own snail farm. And today he raises 70,000 snails at a time, which means he’s gotten really fast at snail shucking.

transcript.author: Knapp
transcript.text: I can do, I’m thinking, about 600 in a half an hour.

transcript.author: Intagliata
transcript.text: That is one snail every three seconds. And nowadays Taylor has all the fresh snails he’d ever care to cook.

transcript.author: Knapp
transcript.text: We’ve done snail tacos and snail and mushroom tarts and ramen and all of these things. There’s one preparation that’s by far my favorite, and it’s an old Sicilian recipe. You cook the snails in the shell, and you stew them for maybe about an hour with tomato and red wine and lots of onion and garlic. It makes this dish called babbalucci. You get a little messy with it. You eat it with your hands and some toothpicks and some crusty bread. It’s just the best.

transcript.author: Intagliata
transcript.text: I mean, count me in on that. And Taylor isn’t the only one cooking these snails. He says he’s supplied snails to the best restaurants in the country: Daniel, the French Laundry, Eleven Madison Park. But five years ago he gets a phone call from this guy named Antonio Cerullo.

transcript.author: Knapp
transcript.text: So anyway, he reached out, and I just thought his, his study that he was working on was really interesting.

transcript.author: Intagliata
transcript.text: The study involved searching far and wide across the animal kingdom for mucus samples—because, Antonio says ...

transcript.author: Antonio Cerullo:
transcript.text: With every mucus sample that we can acquire and research, our global understanding of mucus becomes stronger.

transcript.author: Intagliata
transcript.text: You might remember the researcher with a mucus library from the first episode. Antonio is that same slime guy.

transcript.author: Knapp
transcript.text: And so, getting to talk with him, he started to explain what he was after.

transcript.author: Cerullo
transcript.text: A single species of snail will produce three different mucus.

transcript.author: Knapp
transcript.text: And it was just very fascinating. I mean, it was a whole, I mean, a lot of things I’ve never even thought about.

transcript.author: Cerullo
transcript.text: Every animal on the planet uses mucus for so many important things.

transcript.author: Knapp
transcript.text: So I’d be in there, doing my thing, and I just gave him a pen of snails, and I said, “Here you go. Go to town.”

transcript.author: Cerullo
transcript.text: So for the protective mucus, that, we just simply scrape off the back with a little spatula.

transcript.author: Knapp
transcript.text: I don’t know a whole lot about what he was doing. I mean, there were snails moving on glass plates.

transcript.author: Cerullo
transcript.text: We just put out a fleet of petri dishes and just let them crawl all over the place, just leaving their slime everywhere.

transcript.author: Knapp
transcript.text: And I know they were scraping the mucus off of those glass plates.

transcript.author: Cerullo
transcript.text: And then for the adhesive, we use, take one of those dishes, flip it upside down and just attach the snail to it.... And then we just let it hang for a while.

transcript.author: Intagliata: “
transcript.text: We just let it hang for a while.” Anyway, Antonio gets all these mucus samples and takes them back to his lab, then at the City University of New York Graduate Center, and he finds that the sticky slime, the lubricating slime and the protective slime—they all have different chemical recipes.

transcript.author: Cerullo
transcript.text: And the differences in the composition actually correlate with differences in measurable mechanical properties ...

transcript.author: Intagliata
transcript.text: Meaning the slime recipe dictates its function. And all these variations of slime could be useful for all sorts of commercial products:adhesives and lubricants and coatings—beauty products, too. The problem is that you'd be relying on snails for the raw materials— which throws a lot of variables at your mucus recipe.

transcript.author: Adam Braunschweig:
transcript.text: [It] depends on what the snail ate, it depends on the weather. Is the snail sick? [Are there] contaminants?

transcript.author: Intagliata
transcript.text: This is Adam Braunschweig of the CUNY Graduate Center and Hunter College. He was Antonio’s Ph.D. adviser—and he’s a chemist.

transcript.author: Braunschweig
transcript.text: I don’t think anybody has any idea what a chemist does, so it’s a little vague and a little mysterious.

transcript.author: Intagliata
transcript.text: Adam says there are all sorts of disadvantages to commercializing mucus from animals: There are ethical issues. There are production issues—maybe you find a rare snail that makes some really interesting mucus, but it’s impossible to farm. And there are purity issues—maybe you just don’t want all that other gunk snails put in their mucus ...

transcript.author: Braunschweig
transcript.text: All the proteins, all the sugars, some of the venoms that are in there.

transcript.author: Intagliata
transcript.text: So his solution? [CLIP: “Lightning Strikes,” by Klaus Nomi]

transcript.author: Intagliata
transcript.text: He co-foundeda synthetic mucus company called Nomi Materials, after Klaus Nomi, the German operatic singer with the look of a tuxedoed alien. Adam says naming the company after the singer was his way of paying tribute to what he calls the “lost generation” of artists, like Nomi, who were early victims of the AIDS crisis. [CLIP: “Lightning Strikes,” by Klaus Nomi]

transcript.author: Intagliata
transcript.text: So what is synthetic mucus, exactly? Well, Adam and his colleagues have found that snail mucus has more than 100 different proteins in it, along with sugars, salts and water. Some of those proteins, called mucins, are responsible for a lot of the magical properties of mucus: the stickiness, the lubrication, and so on. So the idea is to make synthetic snail mucins. In the two years Nomi Materials has been in operation, Adam has raised $0.5 million for the company—and $2 million to study mucus at his CUNY Graduate Center lab.

transcript.author: Intagliata
transcript.text: And if you’re wondering who would be interested in all of this, consider that a recent paper from Adam’s lab analyzing snail mucus was funded in part by the Air Force Office of Scientific Research and the Office of Naval Research.

transcript.author: Braunschweig
transcript.text: The military, they work with adhesives, they work with lubricants, they work with coatings. These are all the purposes of mucus in the natural world, and in many cases the behavior of the mucus is superior.

transcript.author: Intagliata
transcript.text: So sub in synthetic mucins, Adam says, and you might end up with a better-performing product that’s also more sustainable. And the implications go further than that—all the way to spaceflight.

transcript.author: Braunschweig
transcript.text: So one of the problems with the helmet dome of space suits is: they fog up.

transcript.author: Intagliata
transcript.text: That’s something you can relate to if you’ve ever been snorkeling or scuba diving: Have you ever tried spitting into your mask to keep it from fogging up? Well, there’s mucus in spit, and mucus absorbs water and prevents fogging. So Adam and his colleagues are playing around with synthetic mucins as a coating for the helmet dome of space suits.

transcript.author: Braunschweig
transcript.text: There needs to be a special coating on that dome to prevent fogging but that also can handle the extreme environments of space. Many times these have very designer protective coatings. But NASA has designated that they still are searching for better solutions.

transcript.author: Intagliata
transcript.text: But it’s still early days for synthetic mucus. It took four years for Adam and his colleagues at the CUNY Graduate Center—and later his company—to go from the idea of making synthetic mucin to actually holding a vial full of the stuff. At this point they can produce five grams a month of pure synthetic mucin powder—about the same amount you’d find in 13 gallons of snail mucus because mucus is mostly water. Or, put another way, Adam says five grams of mucin would be enough to pump out at least 130 gallons of snail mucin anti-wrinkle cream.

transcript.author: Intagliata
transcript.text: That is indeed where a lot of the money is right now. The snail mucus beauty market is already estimated to be worth more than $1 billion—and counting. Because the moisturizing qualities of mucus are hard to miss ...

transcript.author: Knapp
transcript.text: I think we have very soft hands.... I don’t know. [laughs]

transcript.author: Intagliata
transcript.text: That’s snail shucker Taylor Knapp again.

transcript.author: Knapp
transcript.text: They get, they get mucusy. And that’s such an interesting angle that I have because I’m almost trying to eliminate mucus. You know, we can’t ... be giving these chefs a big, slimy, mass of, you know ... In the culinary world, mucus is typically not something you’re going for.

transcript.author: Intagliata
transcript.text: And yet—and yet—Taylor says that after working with Antonio, he has been awakened to the beauty of mucus.

transcript.author: Knapp
transcript.text: Yes, I have grown a deeper appreciation for the world of mucus and everything, you know, all of its potentials. Yeah.

transcript.author: Intagliata
transcript.text: And I have, too! I’ll admit, I hadn’t really given a second thought to mucus before embarking on this story. On the spectrum from wonder to disgust, I’d say I was pretty firmly toward the latter—especially based on the many experiences I’ve had wiping stalactites of snot from my toddler’s nose, something she and I both hate. But when I came across Antonio’s work and found out he had a whole library of mucus and was pretty much obsessed with the stuff—well, I was intrigued.

transcript.author: Intagliata
transcript.text: And learning about how essential mucus is not just for our own health but for the functioning of literally every animal on Earth, how could I not become sort of obsessed with it, too? Mucus truly is magical. And I hope you now think so, too. Science, Quickly is produced by Jeff DelViscio, Rachel Feltman and Kelso Harper and edited by Madison Goldberg, Elah Feder and Alexa Lim. Like and subscribe wherever you get your podcasts. And for more science news, go to ScientificAmerican.com. For Science, Quickly, I’m Christopher Intagliata.
